awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Western wildfire Experiment for Cloud chemistry, Aerosol absorption and Nitrogen (WE-CAN)
awd_abstract_narration:
This is a collaborative effort between scientists from 5 western universities whose research is focused on the study of the emissions from western U.S. wildfire plumes.  A sampling strategy will be employed using a wide range of instrumentation on the NSF/NCAR C-130 aircraft to study atmospheric chemical reactions occurring in wildfire plumes. This field campaign is being conducted in collaboration with related campaigns supported by other agencies: the FIREX campaign by NOAA and the FIREChem mission by NASA. These campaigns are planned to take place in the late summer of 2018. 

The Western wildfire Experiment for Cloud chemistry, Aerosol absorption and Nitrogen (WE-CAN) campaign addresses scientific questions related to fixed nitrogen, absorbing aerosols, and cloud activation and chemistry in wildfire plumes. This research focuses on the first day of plume evolution following initial emissions. The chemistry and microphysics occurring during this time impacts the partitioning of reactive nitrogen, alters cloud chemistry and nucleation, and largely determines aerosol scattering and absorption.

por.por_cntn:
This award resulted in significant improvements in our understanding of the optical properties of aerosol emissions from wildfires. Understanding of these emissions is critical to accurately model the impact of wildfires on global climate, regional climate, and weather. We successfully measured the optical properties (absorption and scattering of visible light) of aerosol emissions from a wide range of Western United States wildfires that occurred in the summer of 2018 from the NSF C-130 aircraft. The publications resulting from this project were only possible because of extensive collaboration between all the research teams, from several different universities, involved in this study. It is difficult to measure absorbing aerosol on airborne platforms and one significant result of this project was to demonstrate consistent measurements of absorption from two fundamentally different techniques: photoacoustic absorption spectroscopy and particle into liquid sampling followed by analysis with a visible spectrometer.

We demonstrated that organic aerosol absorbs significant amounts of visible light both in the short (blue) and long (red) wavelengths. We were able to quantify the amount of light absorption across the visible spectrum caused by organic aerosol, black carbon aerosol and the lensing effect that results from black carbon being coated in organic carbon. We found that, for red wavelengths of visible light, the effective absorption per mass of black carbon aerosol from Western U.S. wildfires is roughly twice what it would be if the black carbon was emitted without coatings. This absorption enhancement, caused by absorbing organics and lensing, does not appear to decrease significantly with physical age over the timescales observed. Additionally, there was no strong decrease observed in this absorption enhancement with markers of chemical age. We also investigated the previously observed process whereby organic material loses its ability to absorb blue light and found that this process did not occur to significant extents when measurements of the entire plumes were considered. That being said, there does seem to be loss of absorption near the plume edges where there is more oxidation. These findings demonstrate that the loss of absorbing ability of organic aerosol, often called bleaching, may be slower than some models presume.

This project allowed for quantitative comparison of chemical transport model results with observed optical properties, that lead to the conclusion that model inputs need further modification to match observations. These comparisons also demonstrated that emissions from the Western U.S. wildfires have significantly different optical properties than those from Africa. By combining the results from the aircraft with results from laboratory chamber experiments, we were able to quantify the amount of absorption caused by specific chemicals found in biomass burning emissions. It was found that the chemical catechol can contribute a significant amount to the absorption caused by organic aerosol. However, it was also found that this absorption decays rather quickly with chemical oxidation.  Finally, the impacts of wildfire emissions on cloud droplet numbers was quantified and the competing effects of absorption and scattering by smoke particles versus their impact on scattering of visible light by clouds was explored.

The project offered many broader impacts. First, the results of this study will impact the scientific community?s ability to understand the impact of wildfire emissions on global and regional climate. Second, the project afforded the opportunity for several graduate students and postdoctoal researchers at the University of Wyoming to conduct research that has led to publications, awarded and soon to be awarded advanced degrees and permanent research positions in the field. Additionally, a number of graduate students from multiple universities participated in a course in which they designed and carried out research onboard the C-130 aircraft. This course improves the ability to maintain capabilities in airborne research for the future. Finally, there have been a number of outreach events both during the field deployment and after along with a number of popular press articles detailing the impact of wildfires on climate and air quality in the Unites States.
